canonical_explanation.text: This chapter deals with geometric constructions using a compass and straightedge (ruler without markings). Key constructions include: bisecting a given angle, constructing the perpendicular bisector of a line segment, constructing specific angles (60°, 90°, 120°, etc.), and constructing triangles given various conditions such as base + base angle + sum of other two sides, base + base angle + difference of other two sides, and perimeter + two base angles.
rules: Only compass and straightedge are used for constructions
To bisect an angle: draw arcs from vertex, then arcs from intersection points
Perpendicular bisector: arcs from both endpoints of equal radius intersect above and below
60° angle: radius arc from vertex, same radius arc from intersection gives equilateral triangle angle
Triangle construction requires specific given conditions

questions.question_text: To bisect a given angle, we use:
questions.explanation_correct: Geometric constructions use only a compass (for drawing arcs) and a straightedge (for drawing straight lines).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Standard geometric constructions require only a compass and straightedge, not a protractor or set square.

questions.question_text: The perpendicular bisector of a line segment AB divides AB into:

options.text: Two equal parts at right angles

questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector passes through the midpoint of AB at 90°, dividing it into two equal halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A perpendicular bisector: perpendicular (90°) + bisector (equal halves) = two equal parts at right angles.

questions.question_text: To construct an angle of 60° using a compass, we use the property that:

options.text: An equilateral triangle has all 60° angles
A right triangle has a 60° angle

questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has all angles equal to 60°. By drawing arcs of equal radius from the vertex and the first arc's intersection, we get a 60° angle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 60° construction uses the equilateral triangle property: all angles = 60°.

questions.question_text: An angle of 90° can be constructed by bisecting a straight angle (180°).
questions.explanation_correct: A straight angle is 180°. Its bisector creates two 90° angles. We first draw a straight line, then construct its perpendicular bisector.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 90° = 180°/2. Bisecting a straight angle gives a right angle.

questions.question_text: To construct an angle of 30°, we first construct ___ ° and then bisect it.
questions.explanation_correct: 30° = 60°/2. We first construct a 60° angle, then bisect it to get 30°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 30° is half of 60°. Construct 60° first, then bisect.

questions.question_text: The bisector of an angle divides it into:

options.text: One acute and one obtuse angle

questions.explanation_correct: An angle bisector divides the angle into two equal parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bisect means to divide into two equal parts. The bisector splits the angle equally.

questions.question_text: To construct a triangle given base, one base angle, and the sum of the other two sides, we need:

options.text: Base, one base angle, sum of remaining two sides

questions.explanation_correct: This is one of the three special triangle constructions in Class 9: given base BC, base angle B, and AB + AC.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The specific construction requires exactly these three pieces of information.

questions.question_text: An angle of 120° can be constructed by:

options.text: Both A and correct methods exist

questions.explanation_correct: 120° = 60° + 60°. Construct one 60° angle, then construct another 60° adjacent to it. Alternatively, 120° = 180° − 60°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 120° = 2 × 60°. Draw two consecutive 60° angles to get 120°.

questions.question_text: Every point on the perpendicular bisector of a segment is:
questions.explanation_correct: A fundamental property: every point on the perpendicular bisector of AB is equidistant from A and B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector is the locus of points equidistant from both endpoints.

questions.question_text: To construct a triangle given perimeter and two base angles, we need the perimeter value and both base angle values.
questions.explanation_correct: This construction requires exactly three pieces of data: the total perimeter and the two base angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Given perimeter + two base angles uniquely determines the triangle.

questions.question_text: To construct 45°, we:
questions.explanation_correct: 45° = 90°/2. First construct a 90° angle, then bisect it to get 45°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 45° is half of 90°. Construct 90° first (bisect 180°), then bisect the 90° to get 45°.

questions.question_text: While constructing the perpendicular bisector of AB, we take arcs from A and B with radius:
questions.explanation_correct: The compass opening must be more than half of AB so that the arcs from A and B intersect on both sides of AB.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If radius ≤ AB/2, the arcs won't intersect. The radius must be > AB/2.

questions.question_text: Construct triangle ABC with BC = 7 cm, angle B = 45°, AB − AC = 3 cm. In this construction, we extend which ray?
questions.explanation_correct: We draw BC = 7 cm, then ray BX at 45°. Since AB − AC = 3 cm (AB > AC), we cut BD = 3 cm on BX. We then join DC and draw the perpendicular bisector of DC to find A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The construction starts with the base BC and the angle at B, creating ray BX.

questions.question_text: Which of the following angles CANNOT be constructed using compass and straightedge alone?
questions.explanation_correct: 40° cannot be constructed exactly with compass and straightedge. 15° (bisect 30°), 75° (60°+15°), and 135° (90°+45°) can all be constructed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Constructible angles are multiples of 3° derived from 60° and 90°. 40° is not achievable.

questions.question_text: To bisect angle ABC, we draw an arc from B cutting BA and BC at P and Q. Then we draw arcs from P and Q of equal radius. Their intersection R gives the bisector ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The line BR is the angle bisector. R is the point where arcs from P and Q (of equal radius) intersect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drawing the ray BR from vertex B through intersection point R gives the angle bisector.

questions.question_text: To construct a triangle with perimeter 11.5 cm and base angles 60° and 45°, the first step is:

options.text: Draw a line segment of 11.5 cm
Draw a base of any length

questions.explanation_correct: In the perimeter method, we first draw a line segment XY equal to the perimeter (11.5 cm), then construct the base angles at X and Y.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The construction begins with a segment equal to the perimeter, then the base angles are constructed at its endpoints.

questions.question_text: To construct 105°, which combination works?
questions.explanation_correct: 105° = 60° + 45° = 120° − 15°. Both methods work using constructible angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 105° can be obtained as 60° + 45° or as 120° − 15°. Both are valid.

questions.question_text: The angle bisectors of a triangle meet at a single point called the incentre.
questions.explanation_correct: The three angle bisectors of any triangle are concurrent, meeting at the incentre, which is equidistant from all three sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle bisectors meet at the incentre, which is the centre of the inscribed circle.

questions.question_text: In constructing a triangle with base BC, angle B, and AB + AC given, after drawing BC and ray BX at angle B, we cut BD = AB + AC on BX and join DC. The next step is:

options.text: Draw angle bisector of angle C

questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector of DC intersects BX at point A (since any point on the perp. bisector of DC is equidistant from D and C, ensuring DA = CA, i.e., BA + AC = BD).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector of DC gives point A on BX such that AC = DC (making BA + AC = BD = AB + AC).

questions.question_text: To construct 150°, we can:
questions.explanation_correct: 150° can be constructed as 180° − 30°, or 90° + 60°, or 120° + 30°. All methods use constructible angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Multiple valid methods exist for constructing 150° using different combinations of standard angles.

questions.question_text: Construct the perpendicular bisector of a segment AB = 8 cm. At what distance from A does it cross AB?
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisector crosses AB at its midpoint, which is 8/2 = 4 cm from A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector passes through the midpoint = 4 cm from each end.

questions.question_text: To construct 22.5°, the correct sequence is:
questions.explanation_correct: 22.5° = 90°/4 = 45°/2. Construct 90° → bisect to get 45° → bisect again to get 22.5°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 90° → 45° → 22.5° through successive bisection.

questions.question_text: Construct triangle with base = 6 cm, angle B = 60°, AB + AC = 10 cm. What length is cut on ray BX?
questions.explanation_correct: On ray BX at angle 60° to BC, we cut BD = AB + AC = 10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We mark BD = AB + AC = 10 cm on the ray from B.

questions.question_text: The number of angle bisectors that can be drawn for a given angle is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Every angle has exactly one bisector — the unique ray that divides it into two equal angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An angle has a unique bisector; there is only one ray that divides it equally.

questions.question_text: Which angles can be trisected (divided into 3 equal parts) using compass and straightedge?
questions.explanation_correct: In general, an arbitrary angle cannot be trisected with compass and straightedge (this is proven impossible). However, specific angles like 90° can be trisected (90°/3 = 30°, constructible).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The trisection of a general angle is impossible, but certain special angles can be divided into three equal parts.

questions.question_text: In constructing a triangle with base BC = 8 cm, angle B = 45°, AB − AC = 2 cm (AB > AC), where is point D marked?

options.text: On ray BX at distance 2 cm from B, on the same side as where C will be
On BC at distance 2 cm from B
On ray BX at distance 2 cm from B

questions.explanation_correct: D is marked on ray BX (making 45° with BC) at distance BD = AB − AC = 2 cm from B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cut BD = 2 cm on ray BX. Then join DC and draw the perpendicular bisector of DC to find A.

questions.question_text: In the construction of the perpendicular bisector, the two arcs are drawn with:

options.text: Different radii from A and B
Same radius from A and B, with radius > AB/2
Same radius from A and B, with radius = AB/2

questions.explanation_correct: Both arcs are drawn with the same radius (which must be > AB/2) from points A and B to ensure they intersect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same radius from both endpoints, and the radius must exceed half the segment length.

questions.question_text: An angle of 75° can be constructed using compass and straightedge.
questions.explanation_correct: 75° = 60° + 15° = 60° + (30°/2). Alternatively, 75° = (60° + 90°)/2 (bisect the angle between 60° and 90°). Both methods work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 75° is constructible: construct 60° and 90° adjacent, then bisect the 30° gap to add 15° to 60°.

questions.question_text: To construct a triangle given perimeter and two base angles, we draw a line segment XY equal to the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The first step is drawing XY = perimeter. Then we construct the base angles at X and Y inward, and use angle bisectors to find the base vertices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The segment XY represents the full perimeter in this construction method.

questions.question_text: After constructing the angle bisector of angle A = 80°, each resulting angle measures:
questions.explanation_correct: The bisector divides 80° into two equal parts: 80°/2 = 40° each.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bisecting 80° gives two angles of 40° each.

questions.question_text: To construct 67.5°, we need to:
questions.explanation_correct: 67.5° = 135°/2. First construct 135° (= 90° + 45°), then bisect it to get 67.5°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 135°/2 = 67.5°. Construct 135° first, then bisect.

questions.question_text: In the construction of a triangle given base, base angle, and sum of other two sides, why do we draw the perpendicular bisector of DC (where D is on ray BX)?

options.text: To find the midpoint of DC
To ensure the point A is equidistant from D and C, making AC = DC and thus BA + AC = BD

questions.explanation_correct: Any point on the perpendicular bisector of DC is equidistant from D and C. The intersection with BX gives A where AD = AC, ensuring BA + AC = BA + AD = BD = given sum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisector ensures A is equidistant from D and C, making the sum condition work.

questions.question_text: Using only a compass and straightedge, we can construct an angle exactly equal to a given angle.
questions.explanation_correct: To copy an angle, draw an arc from the vertex of the given angle, then replicate the arc opening at the new location using the compass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Angle copying is a standard compass-and-straightedge construction.

questions.question_text: Constructing a 90° angle at a point on a line is equivalent to constructing:

options.text: A perpendicular to the line at that point

questions.explanation_correct: A 90° angle at a point on a line is a perpendicular to the line at that point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 90° from a line = perpendicular to the line.

questions.question_text: Construct triangle PQR where QR = 5 cm, angle Q = 30°, PQ − PR = 1 cm. Since PQ > PR, point S (where PS = PQ − PR = 1 cm) is on:

options.text: The extension of QP beyond Q
Ray QX such that angle XQR = 30°

questions.explanation_correct: S is on ray QX (making 30° with QR) at distance QS = PQ − PR = 1 cm from Q. Then we use the perpendicular bisector of SR to find P.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mark QS = 1 cm on the ray from Q at the given angle. The perpendicular bisector of SR locates P.

questions.question_text: Three perpendicular bisectors of a triangle meet at a point called:
questions.explanation_correct: The perpendicular bisectors of the three sides of a triangle meet at the circumcentre, which is equidistant from all three vertices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Perpendicular bisectors → circumcentre. Angle bisectors → incentre. Medians → centroid. Altitudes → orthocentre.

questions.question_text: An angle of 15° is obtained by bisecting an angle of ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: 15° = 30°/2. First construct 30° (by bisecting 60°), then bisect 30° to get 15°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bisecting 30° gives 15°.

questions.question_text: In constructing a triangle with perimeter 14 cm and base angles 50° and 70°, after drawing XY = 14 cm, we construct:

options.text: 50° at X and 70° at Y (below XY)
25° at X and 35° at Y (above XY)
50° at X and 70° at Y (above XY)

questions.explanation_correct: We construct half the base angles: 50°/2 = 25° at X and 70°/2 = 35° at Y, above XY. Their intersection gives the apex A. Then bisectors of angle AXB and angle AYC give the base BC.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In the perimeter method, half the base angles are constructed at the endpoints of the perimeter segment.

questions.question_text: Using compass and straightedge, which of the following CANNOT be directly constructed?

options.text: Perpendicular from a point to a line

questions.explanation_correct: 72° requires constructing a regular pentagon, which is possible but complex. Among these options, 72° is the most difficult and not a standard 'direct' construction covered in Class 9.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 72° is constructible in principle but not directly from the standard angles (60°, 90°) covered in Class 9.

questions.question_text: An angle of 7.5° can be constructed using compass and straightedge.
questions.explanation_correct: 7.5° = 15°/2 = (30°/2)/2 = 30°/4. Successive bisection: 60° → 30° → 15° → 7.5°. All steps use valid constructions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 60° → bisect → 30° → bisect → 15° → bisect → 7.5°. All possible with compass and straightedge.

questions.question_text: How many different constructions of triangles are studied in Class 9?
questions.explanation_correct: Three triangle constructions: (1) base + base angle + sum of other two sides, (2) base + base angle + difference of other two sides, (3) perimeter + two base angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The three constructions cover different given conditions for determining a triangle.

questions.question_text: To construct the angle bisector, after drawing arc PQ from vertex B, we draw arcs from P and Q. These arcs must have:
questions.explanation_correct: The arcs from P and Q must have equal radii (any convenient radius, not necessarily equal to PQ or BP) to find the bisector point R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal radii from P and Q ensure the intersection point R lies on the angle bisector.

questions.question_text: To construct 135°, we can construct 90° + ___°.
questions.explanation_correct: 135° = 90° + 45°. Construct 90° first, then add 45° adjacent to it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 135° = 90° + 45°. Both are constructible angles.

questions.question_text: In the construction of a triangle given base, base angle, and difference of other two sides (where AB < AC), point D is taken on:

options.text: Ray BX opposite to X (extended beyond B)
Ray BX on the same side as the triangle

questions.explanation_correct: When AB < AC, the difference AC − AB is marked as BD on the ray BX extended on the opposite side of the intended triangle (below BC). This ensures the construction works correctly with the perpendicular bisector of DC.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since AB < AC, D must be on the opposite side so that BD = AC − AB and the perpendicular bisector of DC gives the correct point A.

questions.question_text: A protractor is used in geometric constructions with compass and straightedge.
questions.explanation_correct: Geometric constructions use only a compass and a straightedge (unmarked ruler). A protractor is not part of standard Euclidean constructions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Standard geometric constructions prohibit protractors. Only compass and straightedge are allowed.

questions.question_text: To construct an equilateral triangle with side 5 cm, we need which construction?
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has all angles = 60° and all sides = 5 cm. Draw one side of 5 cm, construct 60° at one end, and mark 5 cm on the ray.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All angles are 60° in an equilateral triangle. Construct 60° and mark the given side length.

questions.question_text: If we are given base BC = 5 cm, angle B = 60°, and AB + AC = 8.5 cm, the triangle:

options.text: Cannot be constructed because AB + AC < BC
Can be constructed since AB + AC > BC
Can only be constructed if AB = AC

questions.explanation_correct: For a triangle to exist: AB + AC > BC. Here 8.5 > 5, so the triangle inequality is satisfied and the construction is possible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Triangle inequality check: 8.5 > 5 ✓. The construction is valid.

questions.question_text: How many perpendicular bisectors does a triangle have?
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle has 3 sides, and each side has exactly one perpendicular bisector. So there are 3 perpendicular bisectors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One perpendicular bisector per side: 3 sides → 3 perpendicular bisectors.

questions.question_text: To construct an angle of 52.5°, the correct approach is:
questions.explanation_correct: 52.5° = 105°/2. First construct 105° (= 60° + 45°), then bisect it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 105°/2 = 52.5°. Construct 105° then bisect.

questions.question_text: In the construction of a triangle given perimeter and two base angles, the perpendicular bisectors of two segments are used to locate the base vertices.
questions.explanation_correct: After constructing the apex A using half-angle bisectors from the perimeter segment XY, we draw perpendicular bisectors of AX and AY to locate B and C on XY.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The perpendicular bisectors of AX and AY intersect XY at the base vertices B and C of the required triangle.
